reviews.review_text: I didn't buy this for a long time, despite wanting to try it, because in my opinion, once you'd played one Diablo clone, you'd played them all. And I still hold this opinion to be very true in a lot of ways - for example, Titan Quest, while initally intriguing, became a hellish repetitive single-player slog through to the end that, after 20-something hours of playtime, left me exhasted and scarred. Torchlight, however, surpised me. Perhaps it has something to do with the well-designed classes that aren't quite as derivative as many Diablo-clones, or the deep levelling system that allows so much variation within the same class, or the well-honed difficulty scaling that makes you feel like you're always growing, or perhaps it's all these features combined that make this game stand out.   The controls are intuitive and the mechanics of the game are well-implimented. The enemies are numerous and varied, and there's always surprises to be found in every corner of the randomly-generated maps. The champions and bosses are similarly frequent in appearance, a factor which helps to eliminate that feeling that you're just grinding a way, wasting time until you fight a boss battle. In saying that, playing this game on single player, I did feel like I was taking part in the occasional grind through enemies and loot and levels, which bordered on tedious at time, but playing with a friend and sharing that burden eliminated that feeling entirely.   On the topic of multiplayer, I felt that it could have been slightly better implimented, in that, for one, it took forever for my friend and I to find each other in the server screen, and there was a bug that occasionally stopped us from adding one another without a full game restart. Also, unlike the Borderlands games (the pinnacle of intuitive multiplayer connectivity in my opinion), you cannot see what missions your partner has to do, so you're contantly relying on them telling you what they're up to (via text chat, if you don't have steam chat), and if you're more advanced than your partner, then any enemies that you've killed won't reappear for your partner, regardless of who is hosting the server. Although I'm sure there's a reason for these issues, they seem like really bizarre features to omit from the game. I mean, sure, you may get a tad overpowered if you're allowed to kill creatures a second time round, but is that really worse than your partner being forced to wade through a sea of emptiness, constantly underpowered due to lack of combat? In any case, all I can recommend is that you start multiplayer games at exactly the same time.  Torchlight 2 is a well-made, deep and enjoyable experience, especially with friends, that separates itself enough from other Diablo clones to really stand at the top of the pile.

A great game overflowing with charm and depth! Check it out!  Nilesy

-Quick Review-   Torchlight II is a dungeon crawler game that lets you chose to play as a few different classes. The basic concept is the same as nearly all dungeon crawlers: Explore, level up, find gear, beat the boss, rinse and repeat.    -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:  Oh no! the alchemist is going to bring about the end of the world! You there, unnamed random hero, it's your job to warn everyone, and be just a few steps behind the alchemists defiling touch. As I implied, you're obviously the hero, the villain you will be trying to catch is known as 'the alchemist', whom has been corrupted and destroys all that is in his way.   Game Play:  I sense that most dungeon crawlers are time consuming on purpose, I spent a good 30-40 hours before I beat the game, then I kept playing for another 30 hours to get to max level, and at that point I stopped playing. The whole dungeon crawler genre is criticized for giving us 'carpool tunnel', you click, a lot. you do use keys to cast different spells, attacks, and abilities. So for fair warning, you will spend a lot of time in this game clicking. There is a feature in the game that lets you load up your pet with tons of gear, and send 'em back to town to sell them for you, or buy health potions, basically you never need to go to town to sell gear or buy potions, you're servant pet will do it for you. What does this mean for you, brave adventurer? More dungeon crawling, less vendering trash items! Yay! (Hopefully!)    Achievements:  So I hit 76% completion on this game, I've given up trying to actively get 100% completed for achievements, mostly because RNG (Random Number Generator) hates me. I decided getting above 75% was pretty good for a game with 123 achievements, many requiring grinding. Achievement categories: Beat the game/boss, try doing this, kill this many enemies, open this many of these, do this ____ amount of times, get lucky, play long enough to do this 100,000,000 times. Again, basically I assume that I'll eventually make more progress on this game as I find people who are like 'hey, play this with me!' and I'm like 'okay, I only need to 3,000 more potions! let's do it!' Half of these achievements are from just playing the game, so you can enjoy that, but getting 100% will require a lot of play time. Just a warning :)   Price:  Torchlight II costs $19.99, I've spent 70 hours playing it. That's definitely worth it. Most people will at least get over 20 hours in the game, even if they're not trying to beat it. As always, I suggest getting the game on sale or in a humble bundle, but the stand alone price is very much worth it, based on the amount of game time I squeezed out of it.    Conclusion:  Story: interesting the first time through, it was very dragged out (not in a bad way, really), Game play: click x1,000,000 (over 9,000 clicks used in the making of this review), Achievements: nothing to write home about, Price: very good price based on the amount of time required to play through the whole game. This type of game is best suited for people who already know they like dungeon crawlers, I've played several, if you're new to the series this is a great game to start trying it out with! Just be warned there is a lot of clicking involved. Again, this game becomes a 100 times more fun with a friend or two. But, I did play through the whole game solo my first time.

Current NG+13 Elite Lvl.500 Berserker's save file has been corrupted. Over 600 hours played with the class over the span of 2 years.  (NOTE: I have played 550hrs up to this point with my one and only berserker, NG+8 Elite w/ SynergiesMOD, maxed to lvl.500, all skills unlocked, fully socketted legendary weapons and armor (cast swords) <- The fact that I've spent all of my time with one character 1 class out of 70-80 I have from mods is telling. This should also emphasize how much I've played this game and my experience playing it.)  (This is my first actual review, I thought I would give this masterpiece the honors.)  Intro: To start I would like to say that I will have bias towards the game even if I try to be as objective as possible. Given my playtime and connection to this game, this should be a given.  I found out about this game from a friend of mine who told me they loved the first game but never played the second, I found out about it and decided I would buy it on sale for I think around 10 dollars around the time (forgive me if this is wrong my memory may be wrong). My past arpg's had been only Diablo 1 & 3 and Sacred 2 at the time so I was excited to hop into another being a newfound fan of the genre.   It all started when I clicked that 'New Game' button. Clicked the berserker and typed 'Shaddah'.  Now to the actual review! I'll make each of these sections quick for your reading pleasure.  Gameplay: (Almost Perfect) Everything in this game plays extremely smoothy, response times are instant and combat is quick, flashy, and most importantly fluid.  Except for the occasional bugs like when i try to shift-click or right-click an item to transfer or equip and the ocacsional hiccup everything else is like it says up there in the parenthesis, almost perfect.  Randomization is extensive in this game, loot enemies, levels, basically almost everything in this game is randomly generated, except for things like your chosen character and pet. Graphics mods I would recommend Ink'd & Ink'd for Synergies The Half-Life 2 ENB Enchancer (ran through Torchlight II Directory)  Sound: (Perfect, phenominal with mods) Music fits it's purpose with general orchestral pieces (my favorite being the menu theme) and nice songs that fit the mood, theme and atmosphere of every location.  Phenominal music mods: Diablo II music mod Final Fantasy music mod (includes track from Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross)  Overall: (Amazing game)  Overall this game is a phenomincal package for it's extremely low price and even better it you happen to catch it on sale, the community is friendly and the modding scene from what I've seen, seems to be strong and thriving (mainly being represented with Synergies). The game is, in my opinion, the BEST arpg out there hands down and offers the MOST content out of any arpg I've seen here on steam or played in my entire history with the genre.   Sadly there comes a time where I must mention the cons, because even with my deep love for this game I must point out the quirks and cons.  Quirks and Cons: (ehh?) No OpenGL support? - whenever I've tried this by enabling it through .config the game crashes on start. Shift-tab and Right-click sometimes don't work. With a freely moving camera the detail on the levels is only viewable from the fixed and defualt isometric perspective. Some achievements require online play (just a really tiny quirk for me) Mapworks accesibility and variety is, at times lacking, I found it more worth my time to beat the game again, given the more intresting randomly generated enviroments.  All in all the game is phenominal, the DEFINITIVE arpg, If you love arpgs or are intrested in the genre, or even just want a relaxing game to kill time in, this is a MUST BUY!  To end this I would like to thank all the developers and modders that made my experience possible, Runic Games, Salan and all the other mod authors and players out there! Seeya and happy looting!   Do I recommend this game, yes... hell yes!

An incredibly simplistic Diablo-esque ARPG with  Steam Workshop support  to possibly enhance replayability.  Before starting the game you're given the option to start the vanilla version and the Workshop supported version. You can move your vanilla character to the Workshop version however the character you save your progress with Workshop mods on will no longer be allowed back to the vanilla game.  The game's difficulties range from Casual, Normal, Veteran, & Elite where the differences in these are that the gold drops are lower and enemy damage & health are increased the higher the setting. In Elite mode the game doesn't just feel harder, it feels like more like an endurance because I found myself constantly having to hit, run, heal, hit, run, heal, and repeat wasting more time than I should be wasting if I was on Veteran because everything on Elite can kill you in a flash and it doesn't help that the baddies take a hell of a lot longer to kill because of the artificial difficulty of increased baddie HP. There's a an option to check whether or not you want to activate 'Hardcore' mode for the rest of a character's playthrough where all it means is that one death means you can't play that character anymore so this is really for those who like to be more pressured into being careful to stay alive.  Unlike the first game you now have a choice of 4 classes however the previous classes have been removed though they all use similar & new equipment as the first. Each class has a handful amount of unique skills but I've found that I was really only putting points in an incredibly low amount of them all the way up to the end-game & max level, 100, leaving probably 80% of the skills without even a single point placed. Though effective this leaves the combat to show how simplistic its action is which all-in-all is just hit, run, & maybe heal. No matter how fancy the skills you've put the points on it's still just run, attack, run, and possibly heal up with a potion or a spell so should heavy damage be taken. You can only 'respec' the last 3 skills you've placed points on so you can do a small bit of testing to find out what suits your preference.  The controls for the game are typical isometric ARPG style with the all too likely-to-become problematic mouse-to-move and extensively rebindable keys with the exception of the mouse buttons being unrebindable. I found that the mouse controls can often be wonky; when I try to move to the opposite side of a crowd of baddies to get away from them for some reason the character would sometimes move to them and attack instead despite the mouse being nowhere near them. During critical situations it becomes an incredible nuisance.  Though very diverse in skins, models, & sounds almost all enemy attacks are similar to one another so I found that fighting just became repetitive with the exception of having some new skills to toy with but still overall becomes the same hit & run rule in combat. Even the bosses are fought the same and the way they fight you feel hardly any different from mob attacks.  The environment as well are very limited in variety. The general idea of different types of environment aside from the scenery with some different turns and slight elevations are 'don't walk on this right now or you'll get hurt', some levers or switches you have to activate to progress the game, and putting items in environmental sockets to again further progress.  Normally when anything dies in a map they stay dead. When setting your game to an 'internet' session you can 'reset' the entire world so everything can be killed again. Even all the treasure chests will be up for another round of loot. The multiplayer's functional & pretty basic; go to the lobby, make or join someone's session, and you just play from there either helping one another or doing your own things. Each person in a multiplayer session sees & gets their own loot from drops so there won't really be any stealing of items. If you and some other people have the exact same mods and sometimes load order of mods you can play the modded game with those people.  Despite all its 'problems' and for what it is the game works and does pretty well at what it tries to be even if there's not a whole lot new or special when compared to many other ARPGs like this. It can be good fun to just isometrically dungeon crawl seemingly killing endlessly especially with someone you know but because it lacks special things it can start to be incredibly tedious & repetitive incredibly fast where your only possible source of replayability is likely trying out the different classes, workshop mods, and/or the multiplayer.

Torchlight II's story follows the events of the first game, although those who come into the game without playing the original will not be missing much. Players create their own hero from one of four new classes, and are tasked with preventing one of the original heroes, who has been corrupted, from bringing ruin to the world. The story serves its purpose of giving players a reason to head off for the next quest goal but for the most part is pretty negligible, with the exception of a few rare quests of interest.  The options for character creation are expanded from the original; there are now four classes and each class has options for its gender, hair, and face. Pets also make a return, with a number of new creatures added. The pets are welcome companions, assisting the player by participating in combat, learning spells, being able to summon minions of their own, and even travelling back to town to sell loot and buy potions so the player doesn't have to.  Basic gameplay follows the template used by other isometric and top-down action RPGs. Players move using the left mouse buttons and click on enemies to attack. There are a wide number of skills and spells available, with numerous ways to activate them through various hotkeys and on-screen icons. The game allows for a lot of variety in builds and play styles, with each level up providing points to add to attributes and to upgrade and learn skills. Also provided is a lot of variety in equipment with no class restrictions, with the exception of some unique loot, although a number of skills require a certain weapon type. Loot in the game is plentiful, but fortunately the game makes it very easy to compare picked up loot with that currently equipped and to switch it into the pet's inventory so it can be quickly sold. There will always be the occasional pause midway through a dungeon to conduct some inventory management, however, outside of these pauses the pacing is quick and keeps the action going at an engaging level.  The dungeons are randomly generated in terms of overall layout, but specific areas like boss arenas are preset. This means that when playing multiplayer or a new game plus, it isn't a matter of simply retreading old routes, and the highly enjoyable exploration experience that the dungeons provide is always there. There is always a danger of such generated dungeons becoming generic and repetitive but it is pleasing to report that the danger has been negated as well as could be hoped for. A number of tougher enemies and special challenge zones litter Torchlight II's areas, providing fairly regular breaks from the usual fodder (who can still pack a punch if players aren't paying attention) and making sure things don't get too repetitive. The player character can become briefly stuck in a crowd that's difficult to maneuver out of, but these situations are rare and typically caused by charging in too wildly rather than through any fault of the game.  With the exception of Hardcore mode, where death is permanent, players can respawn without too much consequence. A percentage of gold can be paid in order for the deceased character to reappear either where they died or at the map entrance. Alternatively they can respawn back in town for free. There are four difficulty options to choose from plus a toggle for the aforementioned Hardcore mode. The Normal difficulty is a decent, but not especially challenging, level for newcomers, so experienced Torchlight players will likely want to jump immediately into Veteran.  Difficulty in multiplayer is handled well, with monsters increasing in toughness depending on the number of players. While it's certainly not necessarily to enjoy what Torchlight II has to offer, there can be no denying the enjoyment of playing the game with others and it adds a more than welcome dimension to the game. Those afraid of having their loot taken by comrades need not fear, as players get their own sets of loot visible only to them. There is plenty of postgame content for players to sink their teeth into after completing the twenty hour or so main campaign, either by tackling one of the main postgame dungeons or by starting a new game plus, which keeps the player's progress but levels up all the opponents to match. New game plus might disappoint some, as it isn't possible to notch up the difficulty, so those hoping for a greater challenge in the main story will need to start a new character. The game has also been created with the modding community in mind, so even if Runic's postgame options run out there will likely be plenty of fan-made offerings.  Visually the game looks great, even on less powerful computers, and for the most part runs very smoothly. The art style is great, the environments are all nicely varied, and the UI is clear and easy to use. Even when hidden behind terrain, it's easy to see where the character is and to click on enemies thanks to a coloured outline that appears for any combatant potentially obscured. Spells and skills are all beautifully animated, and it's incredibly satisfying to see enemies explode upon being finished off with a critical hit. Voice acting is generally rare, but it doesn't feel like the game is missing much without it. The key quest givers and few animated cutscenes are voiced, and it's functional for getting the next task across, but there's not enough of it to have any major effect and can be easily ignored without anything being missed.  For me Torchlight II was an immensely enjoyable experience from start to finish. The game is more than welcoming for both fans of the original and newcomers to the series and is high amongst the better gaming experiences I've had this year. It might not bring anything particularly new to the genre, but those who choose to pick it up will be provided with superb value for their money.    Highly Recommended

Torchlight 2 is an excellent sequel to an already outstanding game. Runic Games upped the stakes and 3 years after the release of the first game they came out with a more ambitious, more colourful, more varied and more enjoyable sequel.  Whilst the game features the same gameplay-style as its predecessor, notable (and brand new) elements are the availability of multiplayer and the extended modding capabilities.  Also, the four playable classes introduced in this episode are brand new and those present in the first game do not return. These classes offer the options to create several builds so fully getting to know the characteristics of a class requires multiple walkthroughs.   Pets also return (but with more options) and instead of the retirement of our characters we have the newgame+ mode. Also, a hardcore mode for die-hard fanatics.  Torchlight 2 is a must for Diablo fans. But do bear in mind that this is similar to Diablo 2 and not to its latest installment.

Probably the best hack&slash style game available on the market. Torchlight 2 Review:  For this review I will make an effort to break down and analyze different major aspects of the game.  1: Story 2: Graphics 3. A: GamePlay Mechanics 3 B: Classes 3 C: Loot/Equipment 4: Wrap up and Bonus  1 Story The Setting of the game takes place directly after the events of torchlight 1, the alchemist has broken out of the ember mine that the entirety of Torchlight 1 has taken place in, and you start your character out just outside a major town that he has already been through.  The vast majority of the Game's story is presented to you through dialogs with the various NPCs that inhabit the area. The actual story itself, in my opinion is nothing special and while they did make a decent effort, ultimately it falls short of really sucking me in. (But lets be honest the story isn't why you play the game is it?) having said that I did appreciate the easter eggs that the developers put in including a reference to a very popular game that came out around the same time that has the same basic formula.   2. Graphics The game has a bright and colorful world with matching art direction. All the creatures, NPCs and classes look great, a refreshing break from the bleak and demonic tropes that are prevelent throughout the genre. The Spell effects are cool and they don't generally get in the way of seeing the monsters and such. Since the game has lower system requirements than Diablo 3, and starts out in a lower price point, the equipment and overall graphics aren't quite as impressive as Diablo 3. But, the graphics overall feel more like diablo 2 than diablo 3 does.   3 A. GamePlay Mechanics The Combat is fun and depending on the difficulty, requires a lot of careful consideration on how you build and equip your character. I love it. In many ways, I am reminded of diablo 2 in how the mechanics are structured. Its not quite as deep as diablo 3, but I was not expecting that much. Movement is fluid, and, thanks to the low system requirements it runs at a solid 60FPS on my iMac from 2010.   You have 2 different types of leveling you can do. You can Level up traditionally from gettinng experience which allows you to distribute 5 stat points to whatever you want (instead of them automatically being distributed in diablo 3)  3 B: Classes The Vanilla game comes with 4 classes, each look and feel completely different from each other. The Embermage starts out weaker than others, but as you unlock new skills you find yourself with a huge grin on your face as you wipe out legions of enemies. Just don't expect to be able to take more than a few hits. While with the berzerker you go right up close and personal to the enemies attack quickly and annihilate them. The engineer plays more like a tank, with slow deliberate attacks and skills that allow you to summon helpers to attack enemies or to distract enemies from you. Finally, the Marksman focuses on hit and run from a-far with skills that allow for those types of tactics. Natually each of the characters has many skills to choose from that allow for alternate tactics. Unlike Diablo 3, or Path of Exile once you choose a skill, you have to pay to reroll the skills up to 3 previous skill points can be refunded.  3 C: Loot/Equipment  The loot and equipment is quite similar to other games in the genre (IE diablo clones), with the standard tropes of rarity (IE normal, magic, rare and unique, and legendary) with increasing number of bonus' to stats depending on rarity. Each Class has two types of unique weaponry, however that doesn't mean you can't equip melee weapons on a mage or on a ranged character.  4. Wrap up: I was excited for it because several former developers of diablo 2 were heading up this team. I have played a large amount of the game under VMware while I was waiting for the mac native version. and its safe to say that I've gotten my money, your money, and two other people's money's worth out of the game.The thing that REALLY sold it to me was the Mod Support.  5: Mods!  Well you've beaten the vanilla game, thats all well and good but are you ready for the REAL fun to begin? download the Synergies Mod. What does it do? Well for starters, it adds 3 new classes, that all feel like they belong in the game nearly 700!! new pieces of equipment and weapons, new areas to explore, new enemy types, an end-game and raids. not to mention a rebalancing of the existing skills and classes. I would say that its got more content in it than most expansions's do. I cannot reccomend this mod enough. Unfortunately, there is a maximum of 10 mods per game. (this is gotten around by combining mods into 1 large mod pack) And you cannot play with those who do not have the same mods as you.   6. Rating  In this rating system 5 is average, which means its plenty good just nothing special, even slightly.   NOTE the scores below are weighted against other games in the genre.  Story: 3/10 There is a story, it ends and has no plot holes. But thats about it. Graphics: 5/10 While its not super fancy and flashy like its bigger budget siblings, the art direction is pretty good and ages well Mechanics 7/10 Again, not as deep as bigger budget entries in the genre but still plenty of fun (and mod support really helps with this aspect) Sound: 8/10 Matt Uleman (the composer of the dIablo 1 and 2 soundtrack) did the soundtrack for this game and you can hear echos of his earlier work, and its glorious. Combat: 5 out of 10 Its not great but it sure is quite a satisfying experience overall.

Many dungeon crawlers pride themselves on lootporn. Runic Games realises it's nice to also package in an actual game with your Excel sheet, and manages to build an inviting world with a responsive and satisfying combat system.  The game's story is one of tragic desperation, told across 4 acts, and while I won't spoil anything I suggest you not play this for its storyline, as it doesn't go far nor deep. Don't mistake this for a lack of charm though, as each of the game's environments are colourful and varied. From bright shining deserts to gloomy forests and snowy ... cold places. My eyes were never bored.  The four classes available in the game all have their distinctive styles, but also allow for a large amount of customisation on the player's part. Many different active abilities are available to choose from, which translates to many different ways to play. Within the admittedly limited amount of classes I can almost guarantee anyone will find a build they're comfortable with. A minor point against this is that respeccing is not available in the base game. Modding rectifies this.  Which brings me to my next point: The players. This game has an abundance of that whole consumer-friendliness our industry seems to relish in not caring about. You want mod support? It's in there, ranging from the smallest of tweaks to total conversions. Always online DRM? Don't be so daft, play offline if you like and have a lovely experience. What about LAN? Yeah, LAN support is in, go nuts. Also note the apparent lack of any microtransactions or locked-behind-paywalls DLC. The point I'm trying to make is that if you take the direction of the industry into account when you're considering a purchase, this is definitely not the worst option available.  Lastly, I should point you to its price. This game doesn't exactly break the bank compared to most other releases of this scope.  HowLongToBeat.com  lists the average main story completion takes around 20 hours, that's not counting the side quests in the field, extra dungeons, mapworks (endgame dungeons) or New Game Plus mode.  So what have we got? A 20ish hour flat story with a pleasing coat of paint, well flowing and varied options for combat, single- online- and LAN play and excellent mod support packed into what is a relatively inexpensive game. If your interest has been piqued I highly recommend you play this game, but if youâre on the fence I suggest having a go with the free demo first.

Everything and more!  Torchlight was one of the best hack and slash RPG's to come out between the release of Diablo II and Diablo III. It had us turning our head, if even for a short time, and (if your a fan) rejuvenated our love of the genre with its colorful graphic's, epic loot, and random dungeon generator. While it was fairly generic it hit all the right notes, and except for multiplayer, was the perfect game to play till the release of Diablo III. Then Diablo III released....... Well while some did enjoy it, LOT's of players hated it (not a fan myself) and quickly Torchlight's predecessor was to the rescue.  Now with a full multiplayer mode, modding capability, and overall improvements to the gameplay, Torchlight II is a fantastic sequel to the colorful h&s RPG from a few years ago. However there are some problems. Multiplayer is great to have if you want to play with friends, or have a small group on the net that regularly play. However if you expect the multiplayer to be as fully featured as games like Diablo III, Path of Exile, or hell even Diablo II you may be hard pressed. Its pretty much just a list of people playing and if you want to play with them you can, however most games are locked with a password and the games that do have people playing don't allow you to chat with them or anything before joining to find out what there doing. In fact you can only chat in game which kinda sucks if you want to set up quick runs or do any kind trading. As of late the multiplayer is pretty much dead. Overall I have to say that Torchlight II's multiplayer is not going to be the biggest draw for most fans of the genre. If you play games like Path of Exile or Diablo III for multiplayer Torchlight II may not be for you.  However the overall improvements to the gameplay overshadow some of the multiplayer woes. Simple little improvements and details are what make Torchlight II's gameplay different from other's in the genre. While it will feel familiar to anyone who has played a h&s RPG, things like being able to equip not only a sword but dual wield it with a gun or any other single handed weapon give you the need to experiment with you character. Other things like your pet, make life a little easier for your dungeon crawling hero. Your pet can buy items in town, sell loot you find in dungeons, provide extra storage, and even help you in combat. You can also choose what pet you would like (including a freaking headcrab!).  But the crowing achievement of Torchlight II is its just downright fun gameplay. You will never run out of things to do in Torchlight, Literally. While the games story is fairly generic (pretty much taken straight from Diablo II) the colorful environments epic enemies, fun boss fight, and funny cameos and homages make Torchlight II's story campaign all the more worth it. What most will love however is what you unlock after beating the game. You can just go ahead and do a (New Game +) which allows you to start the game over at your current level and fight tougher enemies throughout. Or you can decide to stay in the Mapworks which is the final hub world. It has all you need with every type of shop and merchant and one particular merchant that gives you random dungeons to buy. You can play these dungeons pretty much forever collecting loot and fighting bosses. This give Torchlight infinite playablity.   Modding is also a big part of Torchlight II. Some people have already created epic mods that act as entire expansions to the game giving you plenty of more hours of gameplay. Modders have also fixed some of the issues with the game like, not being able to re-spec your character at will. While I have not done really any modding I am looking forward to playing some mods later on.  Overall Torchlight II is well worth the 20$ price tag (oh did I forget to mention it's only 20$). Its somewhat lacking multiplayer cant overshadow the excellent hack and slash gameplay. If your like me and mostly play these kind of games for the singleplayer, you owe it to yourself to buy this game. At least give it a chance and get it when its like 5 bucks, trust me its worth it.  Thanks for reading!

I have always really enjoyed dungeon-crawling RPG's (diablo and the like) and so I am also a very harsh critic of them. To that point, I HATED Torchlight 1, but I am actually a big fan of Torchlight 2. More so than Diablo 3 (pre-Reaper of souls) and more so than dungeon siege 3.  This game really did impress me though. The action is fast-paced and quite consistent as well. Gone is Torchlight 1's horrible scheme of 100 levels of same-dungeon-different-layout; now the game plays in more of an open world, where there are connected regions which have various side dungeons (and 'side-quests') within them. You can fill it all in and search for better drops or you can just move foward with the main questline if you like.   I am also quite fond of the skill and ability systems. It is very reminiscent of Diablo 2, more so than the third. You can select which character stats to increase, as well as which skills to level up. You don't really have a skill 'tree' as you are free to select them at your own whim. However, there are 'ranks' for each skill which give you a bonus trait or added effects once you hit certain levels with each ability.  All in all this game can be very addicting. The visuals and text can be a little too cartoon-y for my taste, but it is very easy to lose track of time while combing a new map or thrashing your way through a dungeon and it is fun to take the (short amount of) time to build your character. Plus there's multiplayer, so fun with a friend!

This game is how you do dungeon crawlers right. The story itself is decent with nothing to brag about, Save the world from the Dark Alcehmist and so on, and bits of lore here and there. What makes the game great is the amount of variety in the game.   There are 4 classes, Ember mage, Beserker,Engineer and Outlander in the game, Each with 3 distinct skill trees that offer interesing ways to deal with enemies. Use the Engineers skill tree ' Constuct ' to build Machines that willl cut down foes with machine gun fire, or Golems to smash any oppostion. Play as an ember mage and use Fire, Ice and Lighting for destrucitve effects that you can chain and combo together. Each role has a distinct combat style with each skill tree giving that class a certain role, or multiple. You also get a pet of your choice. Pets act as companions. They will fight for you, carry items and you can even send them to the town to buy and sell items  The level design seems simple, basic and bare-bone at first. how ever looking around you can find hidden quest for secert levels, with of course hidden and rare loot. Locate fishing holes to fish and find certain types of food to feed yout pet and give them buffs. Find shrines for powerfull buffs and and chance to fight bosses for loot. Use portals to compelete challenges for gear and fame. With so much hidden content in the middle and late stages of the game, youll find out it takes much longer to beat a level if you explore enough.  Multiplayer is a great add-on. The loot system ensure no one nabs your bling-bling after a tough dungeon run and all classes support each other in some way. Let the beserker and engineer take the blunt of the attack while the ember mage nukes from a distance and the outlander focuses on the tougher enemies.  Mods have to get attention. You can play two ways. Play default and play with mods. These two act like accounts so dont worry if you think mods will intferre with you default characters. Mods give a huge amount of content. My favorites are the classes you can choose from. You can get mods that add new classes or pets, give 2X the xp or 2x the skill points, unoffical expanison packs, Diablo hud or better lighting, better loot or just a different font. With hundreds of mods you can make the game feel like how it should to you. But you can only have 10 mods active at a time.  All of this for a bargin of $20. The content of this game easily makes it a $60 game but runic games quote' Some people just dont have $60 lying around'. THIS IS HOW YOU MAKE A GAME AND SELL IT. Most triple AAA games falsey advirtise or over exaggerate and end up with a lack luster amount of content and people paying for a decent enough game but not what was promised to them. This is a shallow and deeply flawed game. But to begin talking about why I've come to this conclusion, we're going to have to go back to what exactly this game is, and lay out the basic formula. I will also only be reviewing the BASE GAME, from my experience completing the game on casual, normal, and veteran difficulties with the outlander, engineer, and embermage classes.  In T2, just like Diablo 2 from which 99% of the gameplay for this game was directly stolen (maybe not the right term, since the original creators of Diablo went on to make this), you control a character from one of a few different classes at an isometric view, clicking around on randomly generated maps and killing massive hordes of enemies with abilities unlocked by leveling up. As you explore, you enter various different dungeons, taking on basic 'go there, kill that dude' quests, with the ultimate reward being giant pools of money and randomly generated gear violently spewing out of every chests and boss you fight. It's a satisfying system, and it's the reason that Diablo became such a hit; the addictive quality of the rewards and the chunky, power fantasy combat appealed to both the hardcore rpg enthusiasts, and the more casual players who just wanted to see explosions. In a way, it's the perfect formula for a game, so much so that a lot of the mechanics of Diablo were repurposed and combined with Warcraft lore to create World of Warcraft, which is still one of the most popular mmorpgs ever made and defined the genre for the past decade.  Now with that established, I'm going to start to get into the things that T2 does wrong. I am going to assume a basic familiarity with Diablo or isometric rpgs; if you're 100% unfamiliar with the genre besides my short explanation, I recommend watching a few minutes of a random D2 longplay on youtube to get the idea.  In comparison to slower, more tabletop-rooted isometric rpgs like Arcanum, Diablo's strength is that there's no turn based system, to dodge an attack is not about a percent chance it's about you as the player moving your character out of the way of the attack. This might seem like a dumb thing to bring up, but I think it's an underappreciated aspect of Diablo which was part of its massive success. T2 doesn't understand this at all. Enemies in T2 are not meant to be dodged, there was ZERO consideration in the game for how autoattacks are supposed to be negated by a melee character. If you're playing melee and you're against something that can't be CC'd by the one CC spell you dumped points into (D2/T2 favor highly specialized characters rather than general purpose builds), you're at the mercy of the mob entirely, getting kicked around by nearly-instantaneous attacks; this of course being combined with a heavy level of tracking, where slow â¥â¥â¥ giants will perfectly follow you and spin around like tops to make sure you can never get behind them. Sometimes the harder monsters or bosses will use big wind up attacks, and I think these are the best part of the game as dodging them can get really tense sometimes, but that's totally negated by the fact that the enemies that have these moves ALSO do the tracking autoattack moves anyways in close combat. So what happens is, you take guaranteed damage from bosses, so you chug potions. You chug potions, so now you have a â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ of health regen all the time anyways, trivializing not just the autoattacks, but every attack from the enemy. So, you now stand directly next to the enemy, chug potions, and hold click, with no thought process going into the action at all. There were only a few bosses which challenged this approach on veteran; the Alchemist being one good example, with his laser which pushed you back and did massive damage, but couldn't quite spin around fast enough if you circle strafed. Good use of a unique ability, I just wish that the rest of the game followed this mentality.  For the sake of comparison, let's look at how the embermage has it in this game, in particular. The embermage is widely considered the best class in the game and for good reason. Prismatic bolt, the main attacking move for its most popular build, is an amazing ability, which stacks every possible elemental debuff on your enemies, and can be combined with passive skills for the embermage which causes damage bursts whenever enemies with those debuffs get hit with an attack. The result is that single attacks can proc all the passives at once for HUGE damage burst potential. On top of this, embermage, with a _single_ skill point, can unlock the ability to teleport for nearly no mana cost. This instantaneous teleportation ability alone lets you rather effortlessly kite giant groups of monsters around at no risk of injury to yourself, and also gives you the best possible way to dodge the slower wind up ranged moves from bosses as well. So, to reiterate, the class is a ranged attack class, with the best mobility, cc, and damage in the game. How did anyone think this is fair?  The biggest draw of Diablo and Torchlight is the loot system, and how addictive it can be constantly getting better and better items and finding bigger stacks of gold. But for some reason, in T2 you hardly get any loot at all! Even in the very final dungeon, there's still pickups of 6 gold coins lying around, at a point where a single health potion costs you 400 gold. It's almost insulting, like the developers didn't even consider increasing the gold drops in the later stages, or just forgot. Torchlight 2 often touts during its tooltips that in multiplayer everyone gets their own unique loot drops, which is great. But if you can control drops on that level to give everyone their own, why can I get drops that are exclusive to another class? The class exclusive items were a very obvious place that T2 could've improved over Diablo, but instead it not only has the same problem, it made it even worse. There is no worse feeling than playing singleplayer on an embermage, and getting an outlander-exclusive drop from the boss at the end of an act that's _actually an upgrade for you_, and just vendoring it off. The mechanics and the item stats are all so generalized anyways, all the classes use the same 'charge bar' mechanic for example, so it's like they wanted items to be useful for every build, and then they slapped class-specific requirements on for absolutely no reason I can see besides â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ the player off. There's even a tooltip that says to 'just trade the item to another player of that class!', as if that solves the issue in singleplayer...  Pretty much every track in the game sounds like a variation of the Act 1 theme from D2 with the iconic lute, up until the last boss, and it borders on annoying. Act 3 feels rushed together and isn't anywhere near as exciting as it could've been, mostly being a green forested area like Act 1 again, until suddenly you go through a gate and you're in the hellish awesome steampunk setting of the final dungeon, which is the only memorable locale in the game. The aoe dancing lightning ability some enemies have is bugged and does imbalanced amounts of damage, being able to kill you almost instantaneously. Bosses don't regenerate health if you die to them, so you can just keep respawning, running in, doing an attack, dying, and repeat over and over.  On and on the list goes, but I feel like here I've covered most of the main points. People rate this game highly because at the time of T2's release, D3 was still fresh on people's minds, and that game really was atrocious. So in comparison, T2 seemed like the better game, and it was. But as time has gone on my opinion of this game has very much soured. The complexity just isn't there. The loot isn't fun. The hardest part of the game on veteran was managing my gold so that I could buy potions and have even a chance to survive. If you like D2, chances are, this will be an interesting distraction. But really, the game's disappointing. Not recommended

Torchlight II (Nth Review)  Why is this game revered so much?  Yes, I get that through mods and stuff you can change pretty much anything, but the game itself is not really that good. To call it *the* spiritual sucessor to Diablo 2, at least, is really ridiculous. The graphic style is a matter of taste, and I like it, though quality-wise it is nothing special. 'Nothing special' pretty much sums up the story, as well. Even 'Path of Exile' has more resemblance of a story, than this.  The main problems I had are these:  1. This game throws so much loot at me that I actually get bored by it. What Diablo 3 had too little, TL2 piles onto your shoulders relentlessly. After a while you just quickly check stuff and toss 90% of even rares, uniques, set items and other stuff out the window, because you either cannot use them or have better stuff already.  2. The level of difficulty is a joke. I am no numbercrunching hardcore gamer or anything, but this game is ridiculously easy. Even on the highest difficulty I only died, when the game did something unpredictable or unfair. And that were only a handful of situations throughout the entire game.  3. The character 'individualisation' is rather half-baked: You can only reset your three most recently acquired skills, which makes it completely useless to test new skills from Act 2 onwards. Arguably the true successor to Diablo II, Torchlight is exactly what you want from an action RPG: loot, and lots of it. I've actually spent the majority of my time just playing through the game by myself, but you could easily jump into a server with some other people (or link up with friends) and tackle dungeons together. While there are certain items blocked to certain classes, you don't necessarily feel like you need to specialize with your character. It's entirely up to you what weapon you want your character to use, or what skill tree(s) you want to invest your points in. Torchlight doesn't use a 'branching' skill system, meaning you don't have to have lower abilities skilled to achieve the more powerful abilities in that particular skill tree. As such, you are choose freely from your favorite abilities from each of the three skill trees your class has. Another thing that I like about Torchlight is that you level up fairly quickly. I'm glad that it doesn't feel like you need to grind so hard before you go to the next area / dungeon, because the game makes grinding fun, with frequent leveling and the promise of loot.

I've been a Blizzard fan boy for quite sometime and needless to say, with the lackluster delivery of Diablo III, I was searching for yet another aRPG franchise to take up the slack. Without prior knowledge of who created the Torchlight series I quite obviously and understandably turned to Path of Exile. PoE was free and well received. Although it was 'fun' it left me wanting more still. Fast forward to this years Steam Winter Sale and Torchlight II for 5.00$ seems like the deal of the century for me. As quickly as Runic Games won my heart they crushed it equally quick with the departure of co-founders Erich Schaefer and Travis Baldree. My hopes lie with the rest of the team though to come up with another great sequel in Torchlight III (fingers crossed).  Anyways, on to the actual game. Torchlight II is a hack and slash RPG that changes minimally from its predecessors so that it is different but so familiar it seems like you've been with it for years. The character classes are a welcome departure from our normal warrior,mage,rogue and add a more colorful cartoony element to the game. The story telling although sometimes minimal is enjoyable and a break from large cinematics with more narration and cartoon style cut scenes. Outside of these changes it is a tried and true hack 'n slash with multiple acts (3) - lots of challenging creatures & dungeons - and new and sometimes interesting NPCs as you travel from town to town.   Overall Torchlight II is an amazing game that has all of mechanics you love in a hack and slash game with just enough of a difference to make it stand out from the rest. If hack and slash is your genre then Torchlight II is a must own & play.

Torchlight 2 maintains the innovations that were introduced in Torchlight 1 and in many ways improves on its predecessor in many ways and provides a much better gaming experience.  Co-op mode has finally been added which was sorely lacking in the original game. Instead of just having a solo adventure, 6 players can now co-op online and this is a very welcome addition as it makes the whole game much more engaging.  The art style is still the same cartoony look used in Torchlight 1 but does appear to have more visual effects this time. The maps are now absolutely huge areas with very explorable open area environments and yes, they are still randomized every time you play.  Unlike the original where you only had the option of retiring your character and passing an item over to a new one, Torchlight 2 now introduces New Game Plus modes where you can bring your beloved character over to replay the whole game with increased difficulties. The game also actively supports modding and be prepared to see the many interesting mods that will be crafted for it.  Downsides, Torchlight 2 has a very forgettable story which i didn't even bother to pay attention to, although the main campaign itself lasts for about 30 hours depending on the speed you play. But then again, story is not really the main point of this game. It is most enjoyable when you gather your friends and co-op together smashing mobs.  Overall Rating: 8.5 / 10 This is an outstanding Action RPG on its own, and is arguably even better then Diablo 3 which was released in the same year. Fans of the original Torchlight should definitely pick this up.

Torchlight II is the successor to Torchlight, an Action-RPG Dungeon Crawler-esque game that sends the player through countless dungeons and landscapes killing a variety of different monsters that may stand in their path in order to complete their quests.  Combat is very satisfying, weapons feel like they have weight and it feels great while using some of the bigger ones. Also, the enemies tend to explode. A lot.  The weapons are EXTREMELY diverse, though a lot of them look the same in sprite, and sometimes in-world, you will likely never see every weapon in several playthroughs as many have randomly generated quirks and/or effects. You really are spoiled for choice. Armour is very much the same.  There are a diverse selection of dungeon tiles ranging from Steampunky clockwork looks to haunted crypts and as the Dungeons are randomly generated (with some exceptions) it is unlikely that you'll see the same dungeon again.  Once the player completes the game, they unlock access to a place called the 'Mapworks' which allows the player to buy maps that correspond to their character's level (or not) and run a dungeon which is scaled to whatever map scroll they purchase. Some maps even have additional effects which can affect both the player and the monsters found within the dungeon.

I'm only about 1,5hrs into the game at the time, but it's already a very satisfying game. The visual style is nice and cartoony without being too wonky, and there's some neat little bits of humor sprinkled about here and there. The world feels genuine and familiar for any fantasy gamer and the enemies are varied but balanced.  The soundtrack bothers me, while it's excellently done and easy on the ear, it leans far too heavily on the first two Diablo games' soundtracks and doesn't quite fit the game's atmosphere. Many of the sound effects could also just as well be pulled directly from Diablo, as is the waypoint system, and the socketed items, portal and identify scrolls. I get it, it's made to feel familiar to Diablo fans and that's what appeals to me too, but some of these things just feel like lapses of imagination when the execution is so directly analogous.  It doesn't ruin the game though and the environments have more uniqueness to them, setting the game apart for its own good, and many of the more annoying features of D2 like constantly running back to town to sell stuff to make room in your inventory (you can have your pet do that for you) and playing tetris with your inventory to fit everything (items all occupy a single slot) have been left out.  Pros: +Nice visuals and smooth play even with lots of mobs on screen +Very good controls +The pet is a lifesaver +Takes the good stuff in D2 and leaves out the bad +Game difficulty options cater to a wide audience +Map design is refreshing while staying true to the genre  Cons: -Unimaginative in some parts, especially the soundtrack  Torchlight II is an homage to Diablo 2 and brings it to the 21st century, introducing some neat new features without significantly altering the overall gameplay, and yet manages to remain a game of its own. 8,5/10.
